cluster_classes.class_description: Social groups of rural inhabitants (peasants and villagers) who served as primary sources for the Grimm brothers' collected tales.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: gathering stories from peasants and villagers to preserve the oral traditions

members.entity_description: Rural, lower-class inhabitants of the German countryside who shared oral stories with the Grimms.
Residents of small rural settlements in Germany who recounted tales to the Grimm brothers.

remarks: This parent class is now mostly a fallback for unspecified rural informants after splitting out peasants and villagers; consider deprecating if it remains empty.

cluster_classes.class_description: Rural areas within Germany that serve as cultural and geographical settings, such as those traveled by the Brothers Grimm to collect folk stories.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: traveled throughout the German countryside, gathering stories from peasants and villagers

members.entity_description: Rural regions of Germany where the Grimm brothers traveled to collect stories.

splits.name: German Peasants (Grimm Sources)
splits.description: Rural, lower-class inhabitants of the German countryside who shared oral stories with the Brothers Grimm.

splits.name: German Villagers (Grimm Sources)
splits.description: Residents of small rural settlements in Germany who recounted tales to the Brothers Grimm.

args.justification: The original 'Rural Social Groups' class bundles two distinct but related social groups—peasants and villagers—which are each meaningful and separately referenced sources for Grimm tales; splitting improves semantic coherence and granularity.

args.new_description: Rural, lower-class inhabitants of the German countryside who shared oral stories with the Brothers Grimm.
args.new_class_group: Grimm Brothers Folk Tale Collection – Rural German Context
args.justification: Aligns the new peasants class with a shared class group capturing the rural German context of Grimm fieldwork and ensures consistent metadata.

args.new_description: Residents of small rural settlements in Germany who recounted tales to the Brothers Grimm.
args.new_class_group: Grimm Brothers Folk Tale Collection – Rural German Context
args.justification: Places the new villagers class in the same higher-level grouping as related social and geographical context classes for Grimm tale collection.

args.new_description: Rural inhabitants who served as informants for the Brothers Grimm when not otherwise specified as peasants or villagers.
args.new_class_group: Grimm Brothers Folk Tale Collection – Rural German Context
args.remark: This parent class is now mostly a fallback for unspecified rural informants after splitting out peasants and villagers; consider deprecating if it remains empty.
args.justification: Renames and aligns the residual class to reflect its new, narrower role after splitting and to share the common rural Grimm context group.

args.new_description: Rural areas within Germany that served as cultural and geographical settings for the Brothers Grimm as they traveled to collect folk stories.
args.new_class_group: Grimm Brothers Folk Tale Collection – Rural German Context
args.justification: Connects the geographic rural regions class to the same higher-level grouping as the rural social groups, reflecting their shared role in the Grimm collection context.

executed_decisions.justification: The original 'Rural Social Groups' class bundles two distinct but related social groups—peasants and villagers—which are each meaningful and separately referenced sources for Grimm tales; splitting improves semantic coherence and granularity.

cluster_classes.class_description: Named characters from the Ovidian myth of Pygmalion and Galatea, including the sculptor and his living statue.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: the myth of Pygmalion and Galatea... a sculptor falls in love with his creation, a statue that comes to life

members.entity_description: The sculpted statue created by the sculptor Pygmalion that later comes to life and becomes a living being in the myth of Pygmalion and Galatea.
The sculptor in the myth of Pygmalion and Galatea who creates a statue and falls in love with it.

cluster_classes.class_description: Sources and figures associated with the earliest known origins of the ‘Beauty and the Beast’ tale, including foundational myths and the authors who recorded them.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The origins of this tale can be traced back to ancient myths... found in the works of the Roman poet Ovid.

members.entity_name: ancient myths and stories related to Beauty and the Beast
members.entity_description: Older mythological and narrative sources that inspired later versions of "Beauty and the Beast."
A Roman poet whose works contain the earliest known version associated with "Beauty and the Beast."

cluster_classes.class_description: Entities belonging to the fictional universe of the fairytale 'Beauty and the Beast', including the work itself and its core characters.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Both entities are defined in relation to the tale of 'Beauty and the Beast'—the story itself and its main protagonist.

members.entity_description: A classic fairytale about a kind-hearted young woman and a prince cursed to live in a beastly form, exploring themes of love and transformation.
The compassionate young female protagonist, commonly called Beauty, in the tale of "Beauty and the Beast."

cluster_classes.class_description: Core narrative elements from the fairytale 'Beauty and the Beast', including its central theme, main cursed character, and the underlying concept of the prince’s inner self.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The theme of love and transformation is central... kind-hearted young woman sees beyond the beastly exterior... discover his true nature.

members.entity_description: A thematic pairing emphasizing romantic affection and significant change in form or nature.

members.entity_name: Beast (cursed prince in "Beauty and the Beast")
members.entity_description: The prince transformed into a beastly form by a curse in the fairytale "Beauty and the Beast," commonly referred to as the Beast.
The prince’s real inner character, hidden beneath his beastly appearance.

cluster_classes.class_description: Narrative elements and myths where love drives or reveals a fundamental transformation, such as changing outward form or animating the inanimate.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Both relate to love revealing or causing transformation: a cursed beastly exterior and a statue brought to life.

members.entity_description: The monstrous outward appearance of the cursed prince in "Beauty and the Beast."
A myth written about by Ovid involving a sculptor and a statue brought to life.

args.justification: The entity 'love and transformation' is a cross-work thematic concept that fits better in the explicitly thematic class 'Transformative Love Narratives' than in the more work-specific 'Beauty and the Beast Elements' class.

args.new_description: Named characters from the myth of Pygmalion and Galatea (as known from Ovid and related traditions), including the sculptor and the statue he brings to life.
args.justification: Rename and group more canonically around the specific myth while assigning a clear Class_Group that distinguishes this myth-focused character set from Beauty and the Beast–related classes.

args.new_name: Beauty and the Beast Sources and Origins
args.new_description: Sources, precursor myths, and recording authors associated with the early origins and transmission of the tale 'Beauty and the Beast.'
args.new_class_group: Beauty and the Beast Context and Origins
args.justification: Clarify that this class covers contextual and source material around the tale rather than in-story entities, and assign a dedicated Class_Group for origin/context entities distinct from storyworld and thematic classes.

args.new_description: Entities belonging to the fictional universe of the fairytale 'Beauty and the Beast', including the tale itself and its core in-story characters.
args.justification: Confirm and slightly sharpen the existing label and description while assigning a specific Class_Group for narrative-world entities related to 'Beauty and the Beast.'

args.new_name: Beauty and the Beast Characters and Motifs
args.new_description: Core narrative elements from the fairytale 'Beauty and the Beast', focusing on key in-story figures (such as the cursed prince) and story-specific narrative motifs like the hidden true nature of the prince.
args.justification: After moving the broad theme 'love and transformation' to a dedicated thematic class, adjust this class to emphasize work-specific characters and motifs and align it under the same Class_Group as the storyworld class.

args.new_description: Narrative elements, themes, and examples from myths and tales where love drives or reveals a fundamental transformation, such as cursed exteriors or the animation of the inanimate.
args.justification: Align the class explicitly as a cross-work thematic grouping (now also containing the 'love and transformation' entity) and assign a Class_Group that captures its cross-textual narrative-theme scope.

executed_decisions.justification: The entity 'love and transformation' is a cross-work thematic concept that fits better in the explicitly thematic class 'Transformative Love Narratives' than in the more work-specific 'Beauty and the Beast Elements' class.

executed_decisions.new_description: Named characters from the myth of Pygmalion and Galatea (as known from Ovid and related traditions), including the sculptor and the statue he brings to life.

cluster_classes.class_description: Fictional characters and character groups that appear within the Snow White fairy tale narrative.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Snow White, her wicked stepmother the evil queen, seven dwarfs, and a handsome prince in the Snow White fairy tale.

members.entity_description: A beautiful princess who flees into the forest to escape her wicked stepmother, the evil queen, in the Snow White fairy tale.
The wicked stepmother of Snow White and the primary antagonist in the Snow White fairy tale.
A group of seven dwarfs who assist Snow White against the evil queen.
The prince with whom Snow White finds her happily ever after.

cluster_classes.class_description: Emotion and outcome states that are central to the Snow White story’s conflict and resolution.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Snow White ultimately triumphs over the queen's jealousy and finds her happily ever after.

members.entity_description: The jealousy harbored by the evil queen toward Snow White.
The happy final state Snow White attains at the end of the story.

args.justification: Assign a clear higher-level Class_Group to connect Snow White characters with other Snow White–related classes in the schema.
Align Snow White narrative state concepts under the same Snow White Fairy Tale Class_Group as the character class to reflect their shared narrative domain.

executed_decisions.justification: Assign a clear higher-level Class_Group to connect Snow White characters with other Snow White–related classes in the schema.
Align Snow White narrative state concepts under the same Snow White Fairy Tale Class_Group as the character class to reflect their shared narrative domain.

cluster_classes.class_description: Fictional characters that appear within the fairytale "Hansel and Gretel," including its protagonists and main antagonist.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Hansel and Gretel are the two child protagonists, and the witch is the antagonistic witch from the fairytale "Hansel and Gretel."

members.entity_description: The sibling duo from the Brothers Grimm fairy tale who are abandoned in the woods and discover a house made of sweets owned by a cannibalistic witch.
The witch who owns the house made of sweets and is characterized by cannibalism.
One of the two child protagonists in the fairytale "Hansel and Gretel."
One of the two child protagonists in the fairytale "Hansel and Gretel."
The antagonistic witch from the fairytale "Hansel and Gretel" who is outsmarted by the children.

remarks: Class looks coherent for characters specific to 'Hansel and Gretel'. Note that 'cannibalistic witch' (En_25671ad3) and 'witch in Hansel and Gretel' (En_6901e5e0) appear to describe the same character; this likely requires upstream entity deduplication rather than schema restructuring.

cluster_classes.class_description: Key narrative locations in the Hansel and Gretel fairy tale, specifically the woods and the edible house where story events occur.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: abandoned in the woods... stumble upon a house made of sweets

members.entity_description: The wooded area where the two siblings are abandoned.
The edible house the siblings discover in the woods.

cluster_classes.class_description: The German sibling scholars Jacob and Wilhelm Grimm, treated both as individual figures and as a collective pair responsible for collecting and publishing folk and fairy tales.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Jacob and Wilhelm Grimm, German brothers and scholars, began collecting and publishing these tales in the early 19th century.

members.entity_description: The sibling pair Jacob and Wilhelm Grimm, German scholars and folklorists who collected and published classic European folk and fairy tales such as "Hansel and Gretel" in the early 19th century.
One of the Grimm brothers, a German scholar who collected and published traditional fairytales.
One of the Grimm brothers, a German scholar involved in collecting and publishing fairytales.

cluster_classes.class_description: Literary works within the Brothers Grimm corpus, including the main collection and individual tales such as 'Hansel and Gretel'.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The Brothers Grimm's published collection of fairy tales, including well-known stories such as 'Cinderella,' 'Snow White,' and 'Hansel and Gretel.'

members.entity_description: A classic fairy tale from the Brothers Grimm about two siblings abandoned in the woods who discover a witch’s candy house, included in the collection "Grimm's Fairy Tales."
The Brothers Grimm's published collection of fairy tales, including well-known stories such as "Cinderella," "Snow White," and "Hansel and Gretel."

cluster_classes.class_description: Forested settings that exist within fictional narratives, serving as significant locations for plot events or character actions.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: the forest into which Snow White flees to escape her wicked stepmother, the evil queen

members.entity_description: The forest into which Snow White flees to escape the evil queen.

args.remark: Class looks coherent for characters specific to 'Hansel and Gretel'. Note that 'cannibalistic witch' (En_25671ad3) and 'witch in Hansel and Gretel' (En_6901e5e0) appear to describe the same character; this likely requires upstream entity deduplication rather than schema restructuring.
args.justification: This class contains fictional characters from the Grimm fairy tale 'Hansel and Gretel'; assigning it to the broader Grimm Fairy Tales group aligns it with related works and creators in this cluster and flags a probable duplicate witch entity for human review.

This class groups narrative locations (woods, candy house) from the Grimm tale 'Hansel and Gretel'; they belong in the same overarching Grimm Fairy Tales domain as the related characters, authors, and works.

This class represents the Brothers Grimm, the historical authors of the Grimm fairy tales; connecting them via the Grimm Fairy Tales class group ties the authors to their works and related fictional content in this cluster.

This class groups the literary works 'Hansel and Gretel' and the collection 'Grimm's Fairy Tales'; assigning the Grimm Fairy Tales class group appropriately connects these works to their authors and fictional elements.

This class represents a forest setting from the Grimm tale 'Snow White'; placing it under the Grimm Fairy Tales class group aligns it with other Grimm narrative locations and related entities in the cluster.

executed_decisions.remark: Class looks coherent for characters specific to 'Hansel and Gretel'. cluster_classes.class_description: Groups of people who read, listen to, or otherwise form the global audience for stories and fairy tales.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: global groups of readers and listeners around the world who know and enjoy fairy tales

members.entity_description: Global groups of readers and listeners around the world who know and enjoy fairy tales.
People who read the fairytales and are enchanted by them.
People who hear the fairytales being told.

cluster_classes.class_description: Narrative works and related groupings that are traditional, widely known fairytales, including specific stories and sets of such tales that remain popular over time.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Classic, widely known fairy tales like Snow White and Hansel and Gretel, described as timeless stories and classic fairytales.

members.entity_description: The set of stories including the Brothers Grimm fairy tales and classics like Cinderella and Snow White.
Stories that remain appealing and relevant across long periods of time.

A well-known fairy tale about a young woman (often a princess), her jealous stepmother or evil queen, and seven dwarfs, best known from the Brothers Grimm collection but present in various cultural variants.
A general category term describing traditional, widely known fairytales such as 'Hansel and Gretel.'
A classic fairytale about two siblings who outsmart a witch and return home safely.

splits.name: Individual Fairy Tales
splits.description: Specific, named fairy tale narratives such as 'Snow White' and 'Hansel and Gretel'.

args.justification: ClsC_83b48f24 currently mixes specific fairy tale works with abstract categories and sets; separating the individual tales into their own class yields more coherent, reusable classes.

args.new_description: Abstract categories and groupings of fairy tales, including concepts like 'classic fairytale', 'timeless stories', and sets such as the Brothers Grimm fairy tales.
args.justification: After moving specific tales to a dedicated class, renaming and refining this class clarifies that it covers categories and collections, and aligning the class_group connects it to related audience classes.

args.new_description: Specific, named fairy tales such as 'Snow White' and 'Hansel and Gretel' that are traditional, widely known narratives.
args.justification: Assigning a clear name, description, and class_group to the new split class makes its focus on individual fairy tale works explicit and links it to the wider fairy tale ecosystem.

ClsC_59561fa4 represents audiences for fairy tales, which is semantically related to classes about fairy tale works and categories; assigning the same class_group connects these related narrative and audience concepts.

cluster_classes.class_description: Narrative works that represent the Cinderella fairytale, including the overarching tale and specific literary versions.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The familiar Cinderella fairytale and Perrault’s 1697 literary version of that story.

members.entity_description: A classic fairytale about a young woman who, with magical assistance and a lost slipper, overcomes hardship and marries a ruler; known in many cultural variants including the Grimm and Perrault versions.
The 1697 Charles Perrault literary version of Cinderella that added several now-iconic narrative elements.

cluster_classes.class_description: Key magical motifs and plot devices that define the Perrault-style Cinderella narrative.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Perrault's version introduced the fairy godmother, the glass slipper, and the stroke of midnight.

members.entity_description: A magical benefactor character who helps Cinderella attend the royal event in Perrault’s version.
The distinctive slipper made of glass that Cinderella loses, enabling her later recognition.
The specific moment when Cinderella’s magical transformation ends in Perrault’s version.

cluster_classes.class_description: Pairs linking an author and their specific canonical version of a well-known story.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Charles Perrault’s 1697 publication established the most familiar version of Cinderella.

members.entity_description: French author whose 1697 publication established the most familiar version of the Cinderella fairytale.
The 1697 Charles Perrault literary version of Cinderella that added several now-iconic narrative elements.

cluster_classes.class_description: Fictional personae who participate in the ancient Greek Rhodopis Cinderella-like narrative.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Rhodopis and the king are the central figures in the ancient Greek Cinderella-like story.

members.entity_description: A young girl in the ancient Greek Cinderella-like story who marries the king after losing a slipper.
The ruler in the ancient Greek Rhodopis Cinderella-like tale who finds her lost slipper and marries her.

cluster_classes.class_description: Core narrative elements associated with the earliest recorded Rhodopis Cinderella-like story, including the story version, its cultural setting, and its key plot object.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The earliest known version of the Cinderella story in ancient Greece featuring a lost slipper.

members.entity_description: The earliest known recorded version of the Cinderella-like narrative, a story of a young girl named Rhodopis in ancient Greece who marries the king after he finds her lost slipper.
Historical Greek civilization where the earliest recorded Cinderella-like story of Rhodopis originated.
Footwear item in the Rhodopis/Cinderella narrative that enables the king to identify and marry the heroine.

args.new_description: Narrative works that represent the Cinderella fairytale tradition, including the overarching tale and specific literary versions such as Perrault's.
args.justification: This class cleanly represents works in the Cinderella story tradition; assigning a shared Class_Group aligns it with related Cinderella classes in this cluster.

args.new_description: Key magical motifs and plot devices that define the Perrault-style Cinderella narrative, including iconic characters, objects, and temporal constraints.
args.justification: This class groups internal elements of the Cinderella narrative; it should share a unifying Class_Group with other Cinderella-related narrative and entity classes.

args.new_description: Pairs linking Charles Perrault and his canonical 1697 version of the Cinderella story as a specific author–work relationship within the Cinderella tradition.
args.justification: The members are specifically Perrault and his Cinderella version, so the label and description should reflect this focus and be grouped with other Cinderella narrative classes.

args.new_description: Fictional characters who participate in the ancient Greek Rhodopis Cinderella-like narrative, including the heroine and the king.
args.justification: This class captures characters from an early Cinderella-like variant; placing it in the same Class_Group connects the Rhodopis tale to the broader Cinderella narrative tradition.

args.new_description: Core narrative elements of the earliest recorded Rhodopis Cinderella-like story, including the story version, its ancient Greek cultural setting, and its key plot object.

cluster_classes.class_description: Concepts and instances that constitute fairytale storytelling, including individual fairytale stories and their enduring narrative themes.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Fairytales have been a beloved form of storytelling... with their magical elements and timeless themes... these stories have become widely known and loved around the world.

members.entity_description: Enduring narrative themes in fairytales that remain relevant across eras and cultures.
Individual narrative instances of fairytales known and loved globally.

cluster_classes.class_description: Concepts related to the genre of fairytales, including the narrative form itself and its characteristic ethical themes.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Fairytales as a story genre with magical elements and the ethical teachings they convey.

members.entity_description: A traditional literary genre of fantastical stories featuring magic, archetypal characters, and moral lessons, transmitted through oral and written traditions and enjoyed across ages and cultures.
Ethical teachings or values conveyed through fairytale narratives.

cluster_classes.class_description: Recurring elements that characterize fairytales, including magical features, imaginary beings, and archetypal virtuous main characters.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: These tales often feature fantastical creatures, heroic protagonists, and magical elements that contribute to their sense of wonder.

members.entity_description: Supernatural or fantastical features commonly found in fairytales that contribute to their sense of wonder.
Brave or virtuous main characters featured in fairytales.
Imaginary, often magical beings that appear in fairytales.

cluster_classes.class_description: Abstract notions of uncertainty or the unknown within stories, legends, or cultural narratives, such as unclear origins of famous fairytales.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: the origins of these famous fairytales are often shrouded in mystery and folklore

members.entity_description: The unknown or unclear nature surrounding where famous fairytales came from.

args.justification: Assign a coherent class_group connecting this fairytale narrative-focused class with related fairytale genre, concept, and motif classes.
Link this fairytale genre and ethical-theme concept class into the same fairytale-focused class_group as the narrative and motif classes.
Assign the fairytale motif class to the shared fairytale class_group so its recurring magical and character elements are structurally tied to the genre and narrative classes.

args.new_description: Abstract notions of uncertainty or the unknown specifically within the context of fairytales, such as unclear origins of famous tales and their folkloric transmission.
args.justification: Clarify that this abstract mystery concept is scoped to fairytales and connect it to the same fairytale class_group as the other classes.

executed_decisions.justification: Assign a coherent class_group connecting this fairytale narrative-focused class with related fairytale genre, concept, and motif classes.

Assign the fairytale motif class to the shared fairytale class_group so its recurring magical and character elements are structurally tied to the genre and narrative classes.

executed_decisions.new_description: Abstract notions of uncertainty or the unknown specifically within the context of fairytales, such as unclear origins of famous tales and their folkloric transmission.
executed_decisions.justification: Clarify that this abstract mystery concept is scoped to fairytales and connect it to the same fairytale class_group as the other classes.

cluster_classes.class_description: Culturally localized folk traditions that preserve and adapt the Snow White narrative, distinguished by their specific national or regional storytelling contexts.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The story of Snow White can be found in different variations in folklore from various cultures, including German, Italian, and Slavic traditions.

members.entity_description: Variants of the Snow White story preserved within German folklore.
Variants of the Snow White narrative found in Italian folk storytelling.
Snow White story variations transmitted in Slavic cultural folklore.

cluster_classes.class_description: Traditional European stories and narrative motifs, including the broader folklore tradition and specific tale patterns such as children outsmarting witches.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: The story of "Hansel and Gretel" is believed to have originated from European folklore... tales of children outsmarting witches...

members.entity_description: A body of traditional stories and beliefs from Europe, source of the Hansel and Gretel tale.
A traditional narrative motif found in various cultures, in which children overcome or outwit witches.

cluster_classes.class_description: Mythic narrative traditions that express and transmit a culture’s values, beliefs, and shared stories across generations.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: mythic stories that convey values and beliefs of a culture ... passed down through generations

members.entity_description: Mythic stories that convey values and beliefs of a culture.

args.name: Children Outsmarting Witches Narrative Motif
args.description: A cross-cultural narrative motif in which children overcome or outwit witches, appearing in various folk and fairy tales.
args.justification: The entity 'Tales of children outsmarting witches' is a narrative motif that is not inherently limited to European folklore, so it should be modeled as its own motif class rather than bundled under 'European Folklore Narratives'.
Move 'Tales of children outsmarting witches' from the region-specific 'European Folklore Narratives' class into the new cross-cultural motif class where it semantically belongs.

args.new_description: Traditional bodies of stories, beliefs, and narrative practices from Europe, including the folklore context for tales such as Hansel and Gretel.
args.justification: After moving the cross-cultural motif entity out, the class more cleanly represents European folklore traditions as a regional corpus, so the label/description are adjusted and the class is grouped under a shared folklore/mythic narratives Class_Group.

args.new_description: Culturally localized folk traditions that preserve and adapt the Snow White narrative in specific national and regional storytelling contexts (e.g., German, Italian, Slavic).
args.justification: This class cleanly captures regional Snow White variants and should be explicitly grouped under the broader Folklore and Mythic Narratives Class_Group for schema consistency.

args.new_description: Mythic narrative traditions that express and transmit a culture's values, beliefs, and shared stories across generations.
args.justification: This class represents mythic narrative traditions, which are closely related to folklore and fairy tales, so assigning it to the shared Folklore and Mythic Narratives Class_Group connects it coherently with the other classes in this cluster.

args.new_description: A recurring narrative motif in folk and fairy tales worldwide where children evade, trick, or defeat witches or witch-like antagonists.
args.justification: The newly created motif class should be explicitly situated within the same Folklore and Mythic Narratives Class_Group to reflect its role as a cross-cultural tale pattern.

cluster_classes.class_description: Cultural practices involving the verbal narration of stories to convey ideas, emotions, and values, typically transmitted verbally within communities.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: narrating stories and spoken narratives transmitted verbally across generations

members.entity_description: The practice and process of narrating stories to convey ideas, emotions, and cultural values, such as in fairytales.
Spoken stories and narratives transmitted verbally across generations.

cluster_classes.class_description: Abstract concepts describing how stories affect and connect people, including the human condition and the communicative power of narrative.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: fairytales ... offer valuable insights into the human experience and the power of storytelling to connect us

members.entity_description: The range of emotions, behaviors, and life situations that define being human.
The capacity of stories to influence, connect, and convey meaning among people.

cluster_classes.class_description: Concepts that frame the broader context in which stories connect people, including temporal continuity and cross-cultural reach.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: storytelling to connect us across time and cultures

members.entity_description: The temporal dimension across which stories connect people and endure.
Different human societies and traditions linked by shared stories and folklore.

cluster_classes.class_description: Temporal constructs that situate the creation and transmission of stories in time, including specific historical periods and successive age cohorts.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Early 19th century when the Grimms collected tales, and generations through which stories are passed down.

members.entity_description: Historical time period when the Grimm brothers started collecting and publishing tales.
Successive cohorts of people across time through whom stories and cultural lessons are passed down.

args.new_description: Concepts that frame the temporal and cultural context in which stories are created, transmitted, and received, including historical periods, generations, and cross-cultural reach.
args.justification: Both classes model contextual dimensions for storytelling—time, cultures, historical periods, and generations—so they are better represented as a single coherent context class rather than two artificially separated ones.
This class covers oral storytelling practices, which belong in the same overarching storytelling and narrative domain as the other classes in this cluster.
This class represents abstract effects of storytelling on human connection and fits naturally into the shared storytelling and narrative domain with related practice and context classes.
The merged temporal and cultural context class should share the same overarching storytelling and narrative class group as the practice and effect classes it contextualizes.

executed_decisions.justification: Both classes model contextual dimensions for storytelling—time, cultures, historical periods, and generations—so they are better represented as a single coherent context class rather than two artificially separated ones.
This class covers oral storytelling practices, which belong in the same overarching storytelling and narrative domain as the other classes in this cluster.

cluster_classes.class_description: Cultural elements of Germany, including the overall culture and its orally transmitted narrative traditions that the Grimms sought to preserve.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: to preserve the oral traditions of their culture ... German culture

members.entity_description: Cultural stories and tales passed down verbally across generations in German society.
The cultural context whose oral traditions the Grimm brothers sought to preserve.

cluster_classes.class_description: Conceptual and cultural domains related to the background and transmission of fairytales, including folklore and the historical origins of famous tales.
cluster_classes.evidence_excerpt: Both reference folklore and cultural beginnings underlying the origins and transmission of fairytales.

members.entity_description: Traditional beliefs, stories, and customs shared within a culture that influence or shape the origins and transmission of fairytales.
The historical and cultural beginnings of well-known fairytales, often rooted in oral traditions, folklore, and cultural myths.

args.new_name: German Cultural Heritage and Oral Traditions
args.new_description: Cultural elements of Germany, focusing on German culture and its orally transmitted narrative traditions that the Grimms sought to preserve.
args.justification: This class specifically covers German culture and its oral narrative heritage within the broader domain of folklore and fairy-tale traditions; assigning a precise Class_Group and slightly refining the label/description clarifies its scope and connects it to related folklore classes.

args.new_description: Conceptual and cultural domains related to folklore and the historical origins and transmission of fairytales, including traditional beliefs, stories, and customs.
args.justification: This class covers general folklore and the origins of famous fairytales and should be grouped with related cultural-heritage classes under a shared Folklore and Fairy-Tale Traditions Class_Group; refining the label and description makes its conceptual focus clearer and complementary to the German-specific class.

executed_decisions.new_name: German Cultural Heritage and Oral Traditions
executed_decisions.new_description: Cultural elements of Germany, focusing on German culture and its orally transmitted narrative traditions that the Grimms sought to preserve.
executed_decisions.justification: This class specifically covers German culture and its oral narrative heritage within the broader domain of folklore and fairy-tale traditions; assigning a precise Class_Group and slightly refining the label/description clarifies its scope and connects it to related folklore classes.

executed_decisions.new_description: Conceptual and cultural domains related to folklore and the historical origins and transmission of fairytales, including traditional beliefs, stories, and customs.
executed_decisions.justification: This class covers general folklore and the origins of famous fairytales and should be grouped with related cultural-heritage classes under a shared Folklore and Fairy-Tale Traditions Class_Group; refining the label and description makes its conceptual focus clearer and complementary to the German-specific class.
